required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Spectral Optical Coherence Tomography Findings in Patients With Ocular Toxoplasmosis
clinical_study.official_title: Spectral Optical Coherence Tomography Findings in Patients With Ocular Toxoplasmosis : a Retrospective Study

brief_summary.textblock: Ocular toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of infectious uveitis worldwide. The diagnosis of ocular toxoplasmosis is primarily clinical when it is a typical presentation .With an atypical presentation in the fundus, parasitological diagnosis is a decisive contribution, as well as multimodal imaging. We investigate on vitreal, retinal, and choroidal morphologic changes in active and scarred toxoplasmosis lesions using swept source optical coherence tomography.

detailed_description.textblock: A retrospective analysis of patients diagnosed with ocular toxoplasmosis was conducted. The patients were examined at ophthalmology service of Farhat Hached Hospital in Sousse Tunisia between January 2002 and December 2017. Complete ophthalmologic examination and OCT were done at the initial visit and during follow-up.

primary_outcome.measure: number of prticipant affected with ocular toxoplasmosis

intervention.description: Swept-source optical coherence tomography (SS-OCT) is the latest milestone in retinal and choroidal imaging. Because its wavelength of 1050 nm, which is superior to the 840 nm of spectral domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT), it is able to overcome ocular opacities such as cataracts and vitritis, wich allows retinal and choroidal visualization of eyes whose fundus is not clearly visible. Consequently , SS-OCT allows visualization of the retinal and choroidal vascular networks, even in eyes with medium opacity

study_pop.textblock: Nine eyes of nine patients consecutively diagnosed with ocular toxoplasmosis were included in this retrospective study. The patients were examined at ophthalmology service of Farhat Hached Hospital in Sousse Tunisia between January 2002 and December 2017

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- all patients hospitalized for ocular toxoplasmosis.
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients with non active ocular toxoplasmosis
